awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Effective Numerical Algorithms  and Software  for Nonlinear Eigenvalue Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
The eigenvalue problem is a central topic in science and engineering arising from a wide range of applications and posing major numerical challenges. For decades, it has been the focus of numerous theoretical research activities for developing various efficient numerical algorithms. These efforts have led to the development of new software that is essential to assist the everyday work of many engineers and scientists. In spite of progress made on solving the eigenvalue problem, methods available for handling these problems remain limited in their scope and they have not resulted in effective general-purpose software so far. The primary goal of this project is to fill this gap by advancing the state of the art in solution methods for nonlinear eigenvalue problems which are both mathematically and practically far more challenging than the traditional linear eigenvalue problems. The combined expertise of the investigating team is well suited for exploring new algorithms in this arena, analyzing them, and developing new effective software that can universally impact a wide range of disciplines (engineering, physics, chemistry, and biology). The outcome of the project are expected to open new and efficient ways to solve nonlinear eigenvalue problems. A new suite of state of the art numerical routines will be developed, fully tested, and publicly released.

The goal of this project is to advance the state-of-the-art in solution methods for nonlinear eigenvalue problems. The new approaches that are envisioned are expected to be particularly effective for solving large-scale problems using parallelism. The main thrust of the project is the development of novel eigenvalue algorithms based on generalizations of Cauchy integral type methods for the nonlinear case, combined with projection methods such as Krylov and subspace iteration. A starting point in this investigation is the FEAST approach which will be adapted to the nonlinear context. Because the problems under consideration are expected to be large and sparse, the team will investigate methods that rely on domain decomposition where the original physical domain is partitioned into a number of subdomains in order to exploit parallelism. Among other goals, the team will carefully study the extension of the tools that are exploited in the linear case, such as spectrum slicing (computing eigenvalues by parts), block methods, and iterative linear solves, to the nonlinear case.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Nonlinear eigenvalue problems (NLEVPs) are generalizations of standard eigenvalue problems where the coefficient matrices depend nonlinearly on a parameter. A  scalar is an eigenvalue when the matrix becomes singular when the parameter takes the value of this scalar. Nonlinear eigenvalue problems arise in a variety of  applications in science and engineering, including the dynamic analysis of structures, the analysis of vibrations of fluid-solid structures, and in  computational nanoelectronics, to cite a few example.  The nonlinear eigenvalue problems that result from these modern applications are considered to be among  the most challenging numerical problems to solve.  As scientists and engineers are gradually incorporating more complex nonlinear models into their simulations,  this topic is currently seeing an upsurge of attention from the scientific computing community. In particular, the trend is fostering demand for efficient  algorithms to tackle NLEVPs as well as for a better understanding of their theory.

This collaborative project has helped advance numerical computing methodologies in the area of nonlinear eigenvalue problems.  A specific contribution of the  project is a class of methods based on contour integration that allow to extract all eigenvalues in the contour. These can be viewed as generalizations of a  method for standard matrix eigenvalue problems known as FEAST.  This work has impacted the field of scientific computing in two ways.  It has promoted new research themes in algorithms for nonlinear eigenvalue problems,  among numerical linear algebra specialists.  It has also enabled researchers in the applications areas to have efficient tools for handling the challenging  NLEVPs that emerge from their numerical simulations.  In the past it was common practice to solve nonlinear eigenvalue problems by simply replacing them with  crude linear, or at best quadratic, approximations. This project has provided algorithmic means for solving the actual nonlinear problem and it has made  available effective software for this purpose.

As an illustration of the impact in the applications field, the university of Minnesota team has undertaken a collaboration with colleagues from Rice  university, Emory University, and the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories, which led to significant advances in solving very challenging problems related  to the computations of normal modes of planets. The study of planetary normal modes is important in the understanding of the dynamic response to sources  including earthquakes along faults, meteorite impacts, postseismic relaxation, as well as for analyzing and computing surface and body waves.  However, the  problem is computationally very challenging. When using the finite element method (FEM) in this context, one is confronted with several difficulties.  First,  the FEM discretization must account for various types of material and it leads to a large generalized eigenvalue problem with matrix sizes that must reach into  billions to capture the higher frequencies. The other difficulty is that the original problem has an essential spectrum that needs to be separated.  This  particular work involved the combination of key ingredients from various horizons: complex finite element discretization of the whole planet, effective  techniques for separating the essential and discrete spectra, effective linear algebra methods (University of Minnesota contribution), and parallel processing.  The original problem is actually a nonlinear problem and its linear form is just a simplification.  Recently, the team extended this work by turning to a  quadratic model.

In addition to the articles that have already published under this grant, two papers are currently under review. The first one (Z. Tang, Y. Saad, "A  rational-Chebyshev projection method for nonlinear eigenvalue problems") is on algorithmic aspects, and the second (Jia  Shi, Ruipeng LI, Yuanzhe Xi, Yousef Saad, Maarten V. de Hoop "A non-perturbative approach to computing seismic normal modes in rotating planets") resulted from  the collaboration mentioned above.
